    Each violation of this article shall subject the violator to a fine of $500.00. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate violation of this article. Each day that a special event is advertised to the public without a permit being first obtained shall constitute a separate violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 379,  8, 7-9-97) 
Chapter 18 - TAXATION AND FINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; licenses, Ch. 12; utilities, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Finance and taxation, F.S.  166.101 et seq.; ad valorem tax, F.S. ch. 193 et seq.; local business taxes, F.S. ch. 205; public service tax, F.S.  166.231, 166.232. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Additional homestead exemption for persons 65 and older. 
(a)  In accordance with Section 6(d), Art. VII of the State Constitution and F.S.  196.075 the Town Commission hereby authorizes and allows, as to real estate located within the Town of Lauderdale-By-The-Sea, Florida, and pursuant to applicable law, either of the following additional homestead exemptions for qualified persons: 
(1)  A $50,000.00 exemption for any person who has the legal and equitable title to real estate and maintains thereon the permanent residence of the owner, who has attained age 65, and whose household income does not exceed $20,000.00 (subject to the calculation and adjustment of household income as authorized in F.S.  [196.075(3)] and section (d) below; or 
(2)  An exemption equal to the amount of the assessed value of the property for any person who has the legal or equitable title to real estate with a just value less than $250,000.00 and has maintained thereon the permanent residence of the owner for at least 25 years, who has attained age 65, and whose household income does not exceed the income limitation prescribed in paragraph (a) above, as calculated and adjusted in F.S.  196.075(3), and section (d) below. 
(b)  As to each subject property, the specific additional homestead exemption, if granted, shall be applicable to all ad valorem tax millage rates levied by the Town, and shall apply only to ad valorem taxes levied by the Town. 
(c)  Taxpayers claiming the additional homestead exemption set forth in subsection (a) or (b) above must annually submit to the property appraiser, not later than March 1, a sworn statement of household income on a form prescribed by the Department of Revenue, and supported by any supplemental information as may be required by the Department of Revenue, Broward County, and Florida law. 
(d)  Taxpayers claiming the additional homestead exemption must first be entitled to the homestead exemption set forth in F.S.  196.031. Receipt of the additional homestead exemption provided for in this section shall be subject to the provisions of F.S.  196.131 and 196.161. 
(Ord. No. 481,  2, 11-13-01; Ord. No. 487,  2, 2-12-02; Ord. No. 2007-08,  1, 5-22-07; Ord. No. 2018-28,  2, 11-13-2018) 
Secs. 18-2-18-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 408,  1, adopted Sept. 22, 1998, amended former Art. II,  18-16-18-25, in its entirety which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 270,  1-10, adopted Oct. 23, 1984. 
State Law reference- Public service tax, F.S.  166.231, 166.232. 

Sec. 18-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized utility franchisee shall mean the company to which the Town has granted a franchise to supply the specified utility to the residents of the Town. 
    Electricity shall mean all electrical current or energy for lighting, heating, cooking, power, or any other purpose, delivered to any purchaser thereof within the corporate limits of the Town. 
    Natural gas shall mean all metered natural gas delivered to any purchaser thereof within the corporate limits of the Town. 
    Purchase shall mean every act or transaction whereby possession of, utilization of, control over or title to electricity, water service, or natural gas, and the duty and obligation to pay therefor, become vested in the purchaser within the corporate limits of the Town, but such term shall not pertain to nor include any such act or transaction when undertaken or performed by any agency or instrumentality of the United States government, the State, a county or a municipality, or any presently established churches within the boundaries of the Town. 
    Purchaser shall mean every person legally liable for the payment of electricity, water service, or natural gas rendered to him or her by the authorized franchisee, unless such person is an agency or instrumentality of the United States Government, the State, the County or a municipality, or any presently established churches within the boundaries of the Town. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 18-17. - Levied. 
    There is hereby imposed and levied upon each and every purchase of electricity, water service, and natural gas within the Town a tax in the amount specified in section 18-18 hereof, to be collected as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 18-18. - Amount of tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed by the Town, upon every purchase of electricity in the corporate limits of the Town, included in or reflected by the authorized utility franchisee to the purchaser hereunder, a tax of ten percent, exclusive of governmental charges and taxes, of the total amount shown on such bill. The total amount of taxes due pursuant to this section shall be computed to the nearest whole cent. 
(b)  There is hereby levied and imposed by the Town, upon every purchase of natural gas in the corporate limits of the Town, included in or reflected by the authorized utility franchisee to the purchaser hereunder, a tax of ten percent, exclusive of governmental charges and taxes, of the total amount shown on such bill. The total amount of taxes due pursuant to this section shall be computed to the nearest whole cent. 
(c)  There is hereby levied and imposed by the Town, upon every purchase of water service in the corporate limits of the Town, included in or reflected by the authorized utility franchisee to the purchaser hereunder, a tax of five percent, exclusive of governmental charges and taxes, of the total amount shown on such bill. The total amount of taxes due pursuant to this section shall be computed to the nearest whole cent. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99; Ord. No. 2012-17,  2, 9-24-2012) 
Sec. 18-19. - Application of tax. 
    The tax hereby imposed and levied shall apply to the purchase of electricity, water service, or natural gas furnished periodically after installation or connection and shall not be applicable to installation costs, meter deposits, deposits guaranteeing payment or other charges made by the authorized utility franchisee for availability of service to the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 18-20. - Seller's responsibility. 
    The authorized utility franchisee is required and it shall be its duty to render to each purchaser, bills at least once a month, covering all the purchases of electricity, water service, or natural gas made, and the amount of the tax imposed hereunder shall be entered and shown by it as a separate item on each such bill and shall become due and payable to the Town whenever such bill becomes due and payable to the authorized utility franchisee. Each such bill shall include purchases applicable to but one location, or to but one family or business where more than one family or business uses separate metered services at one location in the corporate limits of the Town. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 18-21. - Fuel adjustment charge. 
    The tax imposed by this article shall not be applied against any fuel adjustment charge, and such charge shall be separately stated on each bill. Fuel adjustment charge shall mean all increases in the cost of utility service to the ultimate consumer resulting from an increase in the cost of fuel to the utility subsequent to October 1, 1973. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 18-22. - Collection of tax. 
    The authorized utility franchisee is hereby authorized and required and it shall be its duty to collect the tax imposed hereunder from such purchaser at the time of payment of each such bill, and to report and pay over, on or before the 20th of each fiscal month to the Finance Director, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding fiscal month. The authorized utility franchisee shall have the right and privilege of assuming and paying the tax imposed hereunder itself in lieu of collecting the same from the purchaser. Failure to timely remit the tax shall the franchisee to pay to the Town a penalty of one percent thereof per month or a fraction thereof during the period of delinquency. Whenever the franchisee shall fail or neglect to collect the tax imposed hereunder from the purchaser at the time of collecting the payment of each such bill, the franchisee shall be deemed to have assumed such tax itself and shall thereupon become liable for the payment of the amount thereof to the Town to the same extent as if such tax had been collected from the purchaser without further recourse to the purchaser. The Town Manager of the Town shall cause to be brought all suits and actions and to take all proceedings in the name of the Town as may be necessary for the recovery of such tax. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-23. - Payment of tax. 
    The purchaser is required and it shall be his or her duty to pay the tax imposed hereunder to the authorized utility franchisee as agent for the Town at the time of payment of each such bill. If the purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay such tax, the franchisee is hereby empowered to discontinue to make any further sales or to render any further service to the purchaser until the total amount, including such tax as is imposed hereunder, shown upon such bill has been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 18-24. - Records. 
    The authorized utility franchisee is hereby required to establish and maintain appropriate accounts and records of all purchases of electricity, water service, or natural gas within the corporate limits of the Town, which records shall show the price charged upon each purchase, the period of time covered thereby, the amount of tax levied and imposed hereunder and the date of payment. The records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized officers or agents of the Town during business hours of all business days. Duly authorized officers or agents of the Town shall have the right, power, and authority to make such transcripts therefrom during such times as they may desire. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Sec. 18-25. - Failure to pay tax. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any purchaser of electricity, water service, or natural gas from the authorized utility franchisee to evade the payment of the tax imposed herein or any part thereof, or to fail or neglect to pay such tax within 30 days after same has become due and payable, unless the authorized utility franchisee has elected to assume and pay such tax. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the franchisee to fail or refuse to pay to the Town all amounts of tax payable to the Town, or to fail or refuse to keep the accounts and records required hereunder or to set forth any erroneous or false information therein with the intent to defraud the Town, or to refuse to permit duly authorized agents of the Town to examine such accounts and records. 
(c)  Any purchaser willfully violating this article or any officer, agent or employee of the authorized utility franchisee willfully violating this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 408,  1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 425,  1, 9-28-99) 
Secs. 18-26-18-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE PREMIUM TAX[3]

ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Uniform accounting, F.S.  218.33; audit procedure, F.S.  166.241. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-61. - Fiscal year. 
    The Town hereby establishes a fiscal year beginning October 1 and ending September 30. 
State Law reference- Fiscal year, F.S.  166.241, 218.33. 
Sec. 18-62. - Municipal accounting procedures. 
(a)  Budget. An annual budget shall be adopted, and the accounting system shall provide budgetary control over the revenue and expenditures of the Town. The preparation of the budget by the Town Manager shall include all requirements of the various functions and activities of the Town. The annual budget shall be presented to the Town Commission for its consideration, possible revisions and final adoption. 
(b)  Fund accounting. The Town's accounting system shall be organized and operated on a fund basis. The diverse nature of municipal operations precludes a single, unified set of accounts for recording and summarizing all of the financial transactions. Instead, the required accounts are recognized on the basis of the various funds applicable in the circumstances, each of which should be completed independent of any other fund. Each fund must be so accounted for that the identity of its assets, liabilities, reserves, fund balances, revenues and expenditures is continually maintained. These purposes can be accomplished by providing a complete self-balancing set of accounts for each fund. 
(c)  Number of funds. The administrative and fiscal requirements, and the scope and nature of activities shall govern the number of specific special funds which the Town establishes. In addition, a general fund shall be established to account for all financial transactions not properly accounted for in a specific fund. 
(d)  Fund accounts. A complete self-balancing group of accounts shall be established and maintained for each fund. The group of accounts shall include all general ledger accounts and subsidiary records necessary to reflect compliance with legal provisions, and to set forth the financial position and the results of operations of the respective funds. 
(e)  Accounting records. 
(1)  The accounting records maintained by the Town shall consist of the following: 
a.  General ledger. 
b.  General journal. 
c.  Cash receipts and disbursements register. 
d.  Receipts for cash collections (in duplicate). 
e.  File containing paid vendors' invoices. 
f.  Employees' earnings record. 
g.  Cancelled checks and bank statements. 
h.  Social Security tax returns. 
(2)  The ledgers and journal shall be posted monthly and financial statements showing assets receipts, uncollected receipts, expenditures and unexpended expenses shall be prepared and presented to the Commission monthly. 
(3)  Bank accounts shall be reconciled on a monthly basis. 
(4)  All funds shall be receipted for and deposited daily in the bank chosen as the depository for the particular fund. 
(5)  All disbursements shall be made by check upon proper approval as prescribed in the Charter. 
(6)  All accounting records shall be maintained in an accurate manner for the Auditor. 
(f)  Valuation of fixed assets. The fixed assets accounts shall be maintained on: 
(1)  The basis of original cost; 
(2)  The estimated cost if the original cost is not available; or 
(3)  In the case of gifts, the appraised value at the time received. 
Cost shall include purchase price or construction cost, plus any additional charges necessary to place the asset in operation. 
Depreciation on general fixed assets shall not be recorded in the general accounting records. 
(g)  Basis of accounting. The modified accrual basis of accounting is recommended for the general fund and specific special funds. This basis is briefly defined as that method in which expenditures are recorded at the time liabilities are incurred, and revenues are recorded when received in cash. However, for small municipalities the cash basis of accounting may be considered to be acceptable. If deemed so by the Certified Public Accountant auditing the Town's financial records, the cash basis of accounting is acceptable for the Town. 
(h)  Classification of accounts. The chart of accounts for revenues shall be classified by fund and source, and the expenditures by fund, function, activity and character. The accounts shall be arranged in such a manner as to meet the requirements of the Town. A common terminology and classification shall be used consistently throughout the budget, the accounts, and the financial reports so as to simplify their preparation. 
(i)  Financial reporting. Financial statements and reports showing the current position of the accounts shall be prepared periodically (preferably monthly) so as to facilitate control of financial operations. At the close of each fiscal year, a comprehensive annual report covering all funds and financial operations of the Town shall be prepared and published. 
(j)  Internal accounting control. The following procedures shall be followed to provide a measure of control over the financial transactions and accounting matters: 
(1)  The careful review of periodic financial statements by an executive who is familiar with the affairs of the Town; and 
(2)  The requirement that all checks be signed by two authorized check signers. 
(Code 1962,  2-6) 
Sec. 18-63. - Annual financial report. 
(a)  The Town Manager shall, in sufficient time to allow compliance with State law, submit to the Town Commission an annual report covering the fiscal year then ending. In making such report, the Town Manager shall estimate receipts and disbursements based on information in his possession. He shall make an estimate of the expenditures and revenues of the Town for the ensuing year. This estimate shall be compiled from detailed information, and its arrangement and classification of expenditures shall be as nearly uniform as possible for the main functional divisions and departments of the Town and shall give in parallel columns the following information: 
(1)  A detailed estimate of the expense of conducting each department and division of the Town government, including all public utilities, facilities and enterprises conducted by the Town; 
(2)  Expenditures for corresponding items during the two fiscal years last past; 
(3)  The amount of supplies and materials on hand; 
(4)  The increase or decrease of demands for the ensuing year as compared with the corresponding appropriation for the last fiscal year; 
(5)  Such other information as required by the Town Commission or as the Town Manager may deem advisable to submit; 
(6)  Estimates of revenues to be derived from sources other than ad valorem levies. 
(b)  The estimates so given constituting the recommendation of the Town Manager as to the amounts necessary to be appropriated for the fiscal year shall be supported with information giving the reasons therefor in such detail as may be necessary to afford the Town Commission a comprehensive understanding of the needs and requirements of the various divisions of the Town government for the ensuing period. Sufficient copies of the annual report and estimate of the Town Manager shall be prepared that there may be copies on file in the Office of the Finance Director for inspection by the public. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 1,  1; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-64. - Annual budget. 
    As soon as practicable after the receipt of the annual financial report and estimate of the Town Manager, the Town Commission shall meet and carefully consider the report. The Town Commission shall determine and fix the amount necessary to carry on the government of the Town for the ensuing year and adopt a budget pursuant to State law setting forth the amounts necessary to be raised for the various departments of the Town. The Town Commission shall appropriate such amounts to the various departments and shall determine the amount of applicable funds on hand, the estimated departmental revenues and the amount of millage necessary to be levied. The budget and millage shall be adopted pursuant to State law. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 1,  2) 
State Law reference- Millage and budget adoption procedure, F.S. ch. 200. 
Sec. 18-65. - Signatures on checks and warrants. 
    All checks or warrants for the payment of money shall be signed by the Finance Director and countersigned by the Town Manager, and checks or warrants drawn upon any bond interest or sinking fund shall be countersigned by the Mayor-Commissioner or Acting Mayor-Commissioner in addition to being signed by the Finance Director and countersigned by the Town Manager. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 6,  1; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-66. - Signatures on contracts, bonds and certificates. 
    Contracts and legal instruments within the Town Manager's purchasing authority may be executed by the Town Manager, or by his or her designee within the limits of the designee's purchasing authority as those limits are defined in the Town's Purchasing Manual. All contracts and legal instruments in excess of the Town Manager's purchasing authority but under $50,000.00 shall be signed by the Finance Director for the purpose of affirming that the Town Commission has authorized the contract, legal instrument, or purchase order and by the Town Manager. Contracts and legal instruments in excess of $50,000.00 shall be executed by the Finance Director, and the Town Manager and countersigned by the Mayor-Commissioner or Acting Mayor-Commissioner. All certificates of indebtedness and bonds shall be signed by the Finance Director, the Town Manager and the Mayor-Commissioner or Acting Mayor-Commissioner. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 6,  2; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010; Ord. No. 2013-08,  3, 6-11-2013) 
Sec. 18-67. - Deposit of fees and moneys collected. 
    All fees and moneys collected and received by officers and employees shall be immediately paid over to the Finance Director for deposit in the depositories of the Town. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 6,  3; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-68. - Payment of claims. 
    No warrant for the payment of any account or claim shall be issued by the Finance Director until such account is approved by the head of the department for which the indebtedness was incurred and by the Town Manager, and such officers and their sureties shall be liable to the Town for all loss and damage sustained by the Town because of corrupt or improper approval of any such claim or account against the Town. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 1,  8; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-69. - Trustees of sinking funds. 
    The members of the Town Commission shall constitute the trustees of the sinking funds of the Town and as such shall be the trustees of such bonds as may be issued from time to time for legally authorized municipal purposes. The Town Commission shall manage and control the sinking funds created for the liquidation of such bonds, subject to the provisions of the laws of the State and the ordinances of the Town in relation to the management of such funds. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 6,  5) 
State Law reference- Sinking funds, F.S.  166.122. 
Sec. 18-70. - Emergency reserve account of the general fund. 
(a)  The Town hereby establishes a separate account of the general fund that shall be designated as the emergency reserve account. The emergency reserve shall be maintained in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles for governmental accounts and the accounting records criteria set forth in article IV of chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Disbursements from the emergency reserve account require authorization by the Town Commission made in the form of a motion approved by majority vote. The interest earned on the emergency reserve account shall be accounted for as interest of the general fund. 
(c)  The Commission shall evaluate the sufficiency of the emergency reserve in conjunction with its review and approval of the annual budget of the Town. 
(Ord. No. 370,  2-5, 12-12-95; Ord. No. 377,  1, 5-14-96; Ord. No. 409,  2, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010; Ord. No. 2018-02,  2, 3-27-2018) 
Secs. 18-71-18-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Supplemental method of making local improvements, F.S. ch. 170. 

Sec. 18-101. - Authorized. 
    The Town Commission shall have power and authority to cause local improvements to be constructed, wholly or in part, at the cost of the property owners benefited by such improvements by levying and collecting special assessments for the following improvements: 
(1)  Extending, replacing, enlarging, improving or maintaining the sanitary sewer system by constructing additional sanitary sewerage mains, pumping stations, laterals, storm sewers and other drains and sewers and necessary appurtenances thereto; 
(2)  Extending the waterworks system into new territory by the construction of additional water mains, pumps, etc., and the laying or relaying of mains, pumps, etc., together with the necessary appurtenances thereto, either inside or outside of the corporate limits or partly inside and partly outside; 
(3)  To pave, repave, grade, regrade, macadamize, hard surface, improve, lay out, open, widen, close, curb, extend, demolish, rebuild and otherwise improve streets, alleys, boulevard, avenues, lanes or sidewalks, including any bridges, culverts, fills, grades or other appurtenances which may constitute or form a part of such improvements, or any parts, promenades, piers, wharves, docks or seawalls adjacent or contiguous thereto; to build, demolish, rebuild or otherwise improve any bridges, grades, fills, culverts and appurtenances; and any one or more of such purposes may be combined in the same improvement; 
(4)  To drain, fill in and redrain waterfront property, swamps, marshes and overflowed lands for the purpose of protecting the health of the inhabitants of the Town, rendering such lands usable and constructing bulkheads, promenades, streets, parking places and other improvements in connection therewith; 
(5)  To clear and clean real property of weeds, undergrowth, rubbish, debris, brush and unsightly and unsanitary matter and to fill unsanitary excavations and depressions; to remove dilapidated and unsightly buildings which constitute a nuisance or a menace to the health or safety of the inhabitants of the Town. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  1) 
Sec. 18-102. - Certificates of indebtedness or revenue certificates. 
    For the purpose of obtaining the money to make such improvements mentioned under subsections (1) and (2) of section 18-101 of this article, the Town shall have the power to issue certificates of indebtedness or revenue bonds or certificates, payable solely from the income derived from the operation of such utility or, where utilities are operated jointly or supplement each other, from the revenue derived from the operation of both utilities or of either utility. Property specially benefited by the extension of the sewerage system or the waterworks system or both may be specially assessed for the cost of such extension, enlargement or improvement, either wholly or in part, by the levying of special assessment liens, it being recognized as a power of the Town in its proprietary capacity to levy special assessments against property specially benefited by the extension of a sanitary sewerage system or waterworks system or both in order to repay moneys obtained by the issuance of revenue bonds or certificates. The moneys collected from such special assessment liens shall be used to pay off and discharge any certificates of indebtedness, revenue bonds or certificates issued to obtain money with which to make such improvements. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  2) 
Sec. 18-103. - Resolution of necessity; hearing. 
    Whenever the Town Commission shall determine that it is wise and expedient to make any of the local improvements specified in this article, the cost of which, or any part thereof, is to be assessed against property benefited, it shall adopt a resolution declaring a necessity for the proposed improvements, describing the nature and extent of the work, the general character of materials to be used, a general description of such improvements, the estimated cost of the improvements and the location or area in which such improvements are to be made. The resolution shall fix a date when the Town Commission shall meet which shall not be less than 12 days after the date of the first publication of the notice provided for in this section for the purpose of hearing any objections or remonstrances that may be made to the improvements. Notice of the hearing upon such resolution shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks, the first publication to be not less than 12 days prior to the date fixed for the hearing, which notice shall embrace substantially all the matters required to be set forth in the resolution of necessity. A copy of the notice shall be mailed to each property owner affected. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  3) 
Sec. 18-104. - Bids on public improvements. 
    As soon as the Town Commission shall have adopted the resolution of necessity as to the local improvement, or at a later date if it so desires, in cases where the improvement is not to be made by regular Town employees, the Commission shall advertise for bids by publication in two issues in the official newspaper before the date of hearing upon the question of proceeding with the improvement, but such publications shall not be less than seven days apart, and the last publication must not be less than two days before the date of hearing. If at the hearing the Town Commission shall determine to proceed with the improvement, it shall let the contract for such improvement to the lowest and best responsible bidder, but the Commission shall have the right to change or modify the improvement if it desires at the time of adopting a resolution determining to proceed, in which event it can direct all bidders to submit new bids within five days without further advertising. When a bid is accepted, the contractor shall not proceed with the work for a period of ten days. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  4) 
Sec. 18-105. - Cost of the improvement. 
    The Town Commission shall have the power to pay out of its general fund, or out of any special fund that may be provided for the purpose, such portion of the cost of the proposed improvement as it may deem to be the proper portion to be borne by the Town. Interest accrued while an improvement is under construction and for six months thereafter shall be deemed part of the cost of the improvement. All engineering and inspection costs, and legal and advertising costs, including a proper proportion of the compensation, salaries and expenses of the engineering staff, properly chargeable to any improvement, shall be deemed a part of the cost of the improvement. When revenue bonds or certificates are issued to obtain money with which to make the improvement, all costs and estimated costs incurred in issuing such revenue bonds or certificates and obtaining such funds shall be deemed a part of the cost of the improvement. When local improvements are made by Town employees, all legal charges, advertising costs, engineering costs, payrolls, materials and equipment rental at the prevailing rates, plus not more than 15 percent of the total of payroll, material and equipment rental costs for general over-head expense, may be included in the cost of the improvement. When the improvement has been completed, the Town Commission shall ascertain and determine the total cost of the improvement. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  1) 
Sec. 18-106. - Method of making special assessments. 
(a)  Special assessments upon the property deemed to be benefited by a public improvement shall be by any one of the following methods: 
(1)  By a percentage of the assessed taxable value of the property assessed; 
(2)  In proportion to the benefits which may result from the improvement; 
(3)  By the foot frontage of the property bounding or abutting upon the improvement. 
(b)  When a majority of the recorded owners of the frontage of lands liable to be assessed for any special local improvement shall petition the Town Commission for any such improvement, the Commission may order such improvement to be made. In other cases public improvement shall be made in the discretion of the Town Commission. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  6) 
Sec. 18-107. - Objections to improvements. 
    At the meeting for hearing objections to local improvements, or at a time and place to which the meeting may be adjourned, any person aggrieved may appear in person, by attorney or by petition and may object to or protest against the improvement. The Town Commission shall consider the objections and protests, if any, and may confirm, amend, modify or rescind the resolution of necessity and shall determine whether the improvement shall be made and how the cost thereof shall be paid. The determination of the Town Commission shall be final and conclusive. If the Town Commission determines to proceed with such improvement as originally proposed or in an amended or modified form, it shall adopt a resolution determining to proceed, as provided in section 18-109. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  7) 
Sec. 18-108. - Claims arising out of improvements. 
    The owner of any lot or land bounding and abutting upon a proposed special improvement who claims that he will sustain damage by reason of the improvement shall present such claim to the Town Commission at the time of its meeting on the question of whether it should proceed with the improvement as provided in section 18-107. Such claim shall be in writing and shall set forth the amount of damages claimed with a general description of the property with respect to which it is claimed the damage will accrue. Any owner who fails to do so shall be deemed to have waived such damage and shall be barred from thereafter filing a claim or receiving damages therefor. This provision shall apply to all damage which will obviously result from the improvement but shall not deprive the owner of his right to recover damages arising without his fault from acts of the Town or its agents. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  9) 
Sec. 18-109. - Resolution determining to proceed. 
    If, after hearing the objections and protests, if any, the Town Commission determines that it is expedient to proceed with such improvement in the original or modified form, the Town Commission shall adopt a resolution determining to proceed with such improvement, which resolution shall disclose what part of the total cost and expenses of the improvement shall be chargeable against and assessed against the property benefited by the improvement and what part or proportion of the total costs shall be paid by the Town from its general fund or any special fund on hand for such purpose. The resolution may direct that the whole or any part of the cost and expenses thereof be assessed against the property abutting upon the improvement or may provide that all property benefited by the improvement may be assessed for such improvement in the manner set out in the resolution. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  9) 
Sec. 18-110. - Assessment roll and notice. 
    Upon the completion of any improvement under the terms of this article, the Town Commission shall cause to be prepared a roll or list to be called the assessment list showing the improvement number, the number of the assessment lien, a description of each lot or parcel of land proposed to be assessed for such improvement, the amount proposed to be assessed against each lot or parcel of land and the name of each owner as shown on the Town tax roll or records. Such list shall be a public record constituting notice to the public of the lien against the land so assessed, and no other record or notice thereof shall be necessary to any person or corporation for that purpose. No errors, omissions, or mistakes in regard to description of property shall be held to invalidate any assessment appearing upon such assessment list where the description given is sufficient to identify the property. After the completion of the assessment list, the list shall be delivered to the Auditor-Clerk of the Town who shall thereupon give notice by publication once a week for two weeks in some newspaper published in the Town that the assessment list has been delivered to him and is open for inspection at his office and that, at a time and place mentioned in the notice not less than 15 days from the first publication, the Town Commissioners will meet to hear and determine any objections or defenses that may be filed to such assessment or the amount thereof. The notice shall state the number of the improvement, the general character of the work which has been performed, the name by which such improvement is generally known, and the location in which such improvement has been constructed. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  10) 
Sec. 18-111. - Assessments against United States, State or political subdivisions. 
    No special assessment shall be made under this article against the property of the United States nor against the State in respect to any lands or real property held by them for public purposes. Any political subdivision or taxing district of the State owning real estate within the Town may be assessed for any benefits to such property and shall be chargeable with notice of the assessment in the same manner as other persons. In addition to the notices required in this article, the Finance Director shall, at least ten days prior to the date of hearing on confirmation of the assessment list, mail a copy of the notice to the Clerk of the County or to the governing authority, as the case may be, of such county, district or political subdivision or taxing district, but failure to mail such notices or any irregularities in the notices shall not affect the validity of the assessment. The assessment shall be entered upon the assessment list, and it shall be the duty of the governing authority of the county, district, political subdivision or taxing district to pay the assessment out of any funds available for that purpose or, if there are no funds available, to levy and collect a sufficient amount at the next annual levy to pay the amount of the assessment, and such assessments shall not be a lien on such property nor shall the provisions of this article authorizing the sale of property for unpaid special assessments be applicable, but such lien may be enforced by appropriate action against the taxing division. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  11; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-112. - Hearing objections to and confirmation of assessment list. 
    At the time fixed in the notice for hearing objections or defenses to assessments for local improvements, or at an adjourned meeting, the Town Commission shall hear objections to the amount of such assessment which may be made by the owners of real property assessed for such improvement or by parties having an interest therein, and the Town Commission shall determine and hear all objections and protests to the proposed assessments under such rules and regulations as it may adopt. The Town Commission shall have a right to change or adjust any assessment appearing upon such assessment list at such meeting or at any adjourned meeting thereof. When such assessment list has been finally corrected and adjusted, the Town Commission shall adopt a resolution approving and confirming the assessment list and shall approve and confirm all assessments as finally fixed and adjusted at such hearing, and such assessments shall, from the date of confirmation by such resolution, constitute a lien on the respective lots or parcels of land, or other real property upon which they are levied, superior to all other liens, except those for Town and County taxes. All persons who fail to object to the proposed assessments in the manner provided in this article shall be deemed to have consented to and approved the assessments. All persons who appeared at such hearing and whose objections were overruled or denied shall be deemed to be bound by the action of the Town Commission after 30 days from the adoption of such resolution approving and confirming the assessment list unless suit challenging such assessment is filed. Substantial compliance with the procedure outlined shall be all that is necessary to render such assessment liens valid and incontestable, it being the expressed intention of the legislature that the requirements are directory rather than mandatory. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  12) 
Sec. 18-113. - Setting aside special assessments. 
    If any special assessment made under the terms of this article to defray the whole or part of the expense of any local improvement shall be either in whole or in part annulled, vacated or set aside by the judgment of any court or if the Town Commission shall be satisfied that any assessment is so irregular or defective that the assessment cannot be enforced and collected or if the Town Commission shall have omitted to make such assessment when it might have done so, the Town Commission is hereby authorized to take all steps to cause a new assessment for the whole or any part of any improvement or against any property benefited by any improvement following as near as may be under the circumstances the provisions of this article. If such second assessment is annulled, the Town Commission may obtain and make other assessments until a valid assessment is made. No omission, informality or irregularity in the proceedings preliminary to the making of any special assessment shall affect the validity of the assessment, where the assessment list has been confirmed by the Town Commission, and the assessment list and the record thereof kept, the Finance Director shall be competent and sufficient evidence that the assessment was duly levied and the assessment list duly made and adopted and that all other proceedings necessary to the adoption of the assessment list were duly had, taken and performed as required by this article, and no variance from the directions contained in this article as to the form and manner of any of the proceedings shall be held material, unless it is clearly shown that the party objecting was materially injured thereby. If any special assessment shall, in any suit where its validity is questioned, be adjudged invalid, the Town Commission may in its discretion notify the Finance Director to cease the collection of the assessment if it has been transmitted to him for collection. The Town Commission may proceed a new by proceedings either as in case of an original special assessment for the same purpose or by taking up the previous proceedings at any point and may make and levy a new assessment in the place and stead of the assessment which shall have been adjudged invalid, and the Finance Director shall ascertain and note thereon payments which have been made on such invalid assessment for the same purpose, which notation shall cancel the assessments as to the parcels and lots on which such payments were made to the extent of the payments. Such new assessments shall be collected in the same manner as original special assessments. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  13; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-114. - Suits, actions, writs or special proceedings. 
    For the period of 30 days after the date of the confirmation of any special assessment levied under the terms of this article, any person aggrieved shall have the right to contest the legality thereof by suit, action, writ or special proceedings, after which time no suit, action, writ or special proceedings in any manner questioning the legality of the special assessment shall lie for any cause whatsoever. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  14) 
Sec. 18-115. - Method of collection. 
    The resolution approving and confirming the assessment list for local improvements shall provide whether such special assessments shall be payable in cash within 30 days from the adoption of such resolution or whether such special assessments shall be payable in annual installments not exceeding seven annual installments, in the discretion of the Town Commission, the first of which shall be payable on or before the expiration of 30 days from the date of confirmation. If the Town Commission desires that the assessment shall be payable in annual installments, it shall fix an interest rate not to exceed eight percent per annum upon such unpaid installments. The owner of the property desiring to pay his assessment in installments, if permitted, shall, on or before 30 days from the confirmation of such assessments, file with the Finance Director a written application to pay the assessment in installments, which application shall state that the applicant and property owner waives all irregularities or defects, constitutional, jurisdictional or otherwise, in the proceedings for the improvement for which the assessments are levied and in the apportionment of the cost thereof, and thereafter the validity of such assessments shall not be called in question. The payment of an assessment, in whole or in part, shall constitute a waiver of all defects, constitutional, jurisdictional or otherwise, in the proceedings. The application shall also contain an agreement that the applicant and property owner will pay the assessment in installments at the date fixed by the resolution, with interest at the rates specified in the resolution. The application shall also make a reference to the number of the improvement and shall contain a description of the lot or parcel of property of the applicant assessed for such improvement. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  15; Charter Amendment, June 3, 1952; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-116. - Lien docket. 
    The Finance Director shall keep all applications for installment payments of the special assessments levied under this article in convenient forms for examination, and such applications shall show the date of filing, the name of the applicant, the amount of the assessment as shown in the application and the number of installments in which the assessment shall be payable. Such approved assessment list and such applications shall constitute a docket and shall stand as a lien docket for the assessment in favor of the Town against such lot or parcel of land until such assessment and interest and penalties are paid in the manner provided in this article. Such approved assessment list or roll shall be the official record to evidence the lien, and the form or manner of keeping and preserving the assessment list or roll shall not be material so long as such list or roll contains the necessary information and is prepared and approved in the manner specified in this article. All unpaid assessments, penalties and interest shall be and shall constitute a lien on each lot or parcel of land, respectively, in favor of the Town, and such lien shall have priority over all other liens and encumbrances whatsoever, except liens for Town and County taxes. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  16; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Sec. 18-117. - Special assessment revolving fund. 
    The Town Commission shall have the right to create by ordinance any special assessment revolving fund out of which may be paid the cost of any proposed improvement where special assessments are levied or are to be levied to pay all or any portion of the cost of such improvement. Moneys raised or appropriated for the purpose of making improvements where special assessments are to be levied to repay all of or a portion of the cost thereof may be deposited in such special assessment revolving fund, and the proceeds from the collection of principal and interest of any such assessment liens shall be deposited to the credit of and shall replenish the fund. The Town shall transfer to such fund yearly from the general fund or other source of revenue an amount not less than the Town's portion of the cost of the improvements made from moneys in such fund. Such special assessment revolving fund shall constitute a permanent fund to be used for the purpose of paying the cost of local improvements, where the proceeds of the assessment liens levied in connection therewith are to be deposited in the fund as collected. The moneys in such special assessment revolving fund at the close of the fiscal year shall not be transferred or appropriated to any other fund, but shall be used exclusively for the purposes of making local improvements where special assessments are to be levied to repay all or a part of the cost thereof. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  17) 
Sec. 18-118. - Assessment liens not assignable. 
    Assessment liens for local improvements are not assignable or transferable, but when the liens are defaulted they shall be foreclosed by the Town. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  18) 
Sec. 18-119. - Assessments validated. 
    All assessments and liens for sidewalks, street improvements, sewer assessments or other public improvements and all collection of such assessments and liens heretofore made by the Town are hereby legalized and declared valid and of full force, virtue and effect, binding in law or equity; and such assessments and liens shall not be set aside or invalidated because of any error, defect, informality or omission which shall not amount to a want of due process of law under the Constitution of the State or the Constitution of the United States. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. X, Art. 7,  2) 
Sec. 18-120. - Foreclosure. 
    Should any assessment lien remain in the hands of the Town and be in default and remain in default for a period of 90 days after becoming due and payable, it shall be the duty of the Finance Director to forward to the Town Attorney for collection a certified list of such assessment liens. It shall be the duty of the Town Attorney to institute foreclosure proceedings to foreclose the assessment liens against the property encumbered thereby and against which the lien exists, and the owner of the property against which the lien exists shall be liable to the Town for a reasonable attorney's fee with which to compensate the Town Attorney for services in collecting the amounts due on the lien. The final decree to be entered shall decree the amount of the lien and reasonable attorney's fees and all costs occasioned or necessitated by such foreclosure as a lien against the property described. The lien for the attorney's fees and costs shall arise whenever the lien is placed in the hands of the Town Attorney for collection, and such lien for the attorney's fees shall not exceed 15 percent of the amount due. In foreclosing such special assessment liens, the Town may pursue and follow any recognized chancery proceeding to enforce liens, and upon such suit being brought, a certified copy of the assessment list and of the resolution approving and confirming the assessment list shall constitute prima facie evidence of the amount and existence of the lien upon the property described. The decree rendered in the case for the enforcement and collection of the amount due shall provide for a reasonable attorney's fee for the institution of the suit and the collection of the amount due on the lien, together with all costs occasioned in bringing the suit and foreclosing the lien, and such fees and costs shall be decreed to be a lien upon the lands described and shall be collected at the time and in the manner provided for the collection of the amount evidenced by the assessment lien. Any number of assessment liens may be foreclosed in one chancery action and the final decree to be entered shall determine the principal interest, costs and the attorney's fees to be chargeable against each property encumbered. 
(Sp. Acts 1951, Ch. 27675, Pt. VII, Art. 5,  19; Ord. No. 2010-03,  4, 8-25-2010) 
Secs. 18-121-18-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - INVESTMENT PLAN 

Sec. 18-131. - Scope. 
    There is hereby created the Town of Lauderdale-By-The-Sea's Investment Plan which shall provide exclusive authorization, regulation, guidance and requirements pertaining to the investment activities of the Town of Lauderdale-By-The-Sea. These policies shall pertain to only those funds in excess of those required to meet the Town's short-term expenses. Financial assets including general fund reserves, debt service funds, special revenue funds, enterprise funds, internal service funds, and other funds which may be created from time to time, shall be administered in accordance with this investment policy. This policy shall not pertain to pension, trust, or bond funds where there are other policies or indenture requirements in effect. 
(Ord. No. 372,  2, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-132. - Objectives. 
(a)  The objectives of the Town's investment plan are as follows in order of priority: 
(1)  Preservation of capital; 
(2)  Liquidity; 
(3)  Investment yield. 
(b)  Preservation of capital. The Town will ensure the safety and preservation of its invested funds by limiting risk wherever possible. A discussion of the types of investment risk follows: 
(1)  Default risk. Default risk applies to the failure of an issuer of a security or other debt-related instrument to return either principal or interest on it. Included within default risk is the potential failure of an issuer or firm in the secondary securities market to deliver a security in return for payment which has been received. The Town will mitigate the effects of default risk by investing in only the safest types of securities as further detailed in section [18-133], eligible securities; pre-qualifying all financial institutions and securities dealers with whom the Town does business as further detailed in section [18-134], qualifications of financial institutions, and requiring delivery versus payment (DVP) for all transactions involving book entry securities. 
(2)  Market risk. Market risk applies to the potential fluctuation in value of a security during the period in which it is held. In the case of a bond, its yield to maturity is known at the time of purchase as is the amount of principal to be returned at maturity. If the bond is sold prior to its maturity, the amount of principal received depends on market conditions. The potential exists for either gain or loss of capital on sale prior to maturity. The Town will mitigate the effects of market risk by structuring the investment portfolio so that security maturities approximate a conservative estimate of cash requirements, thereby avoiding the need to sell securities in the open market prior to their maturity. 
(3)  Sovereign risk. Sovereign risk applies to the potential fluctuation in value of securities in overseas markets. Investments can be dollar or otherwise denominated and placed with foreign institutions or foreign subsidiaries of United States institutions. The Town will avoid sovereign risk in its entirety by investing only in dollar-denominated instruments of United States institutions as detailed further in section [18-133], eligible securities. 
(4)  Reinvestment risk. Reinvestment risk applies to the potential movement of interest rates during the holding period of a group of securities. Reinvestment risk is associated with the potential loss of future interest gain rather than the loss of capital. The Town will mitigate the effects of reinvestment risk by: investing funds that are not associated with anticipated future cash requirement through a range of maturities; and conservatively lengthening maturities when yields are above historical averages and shortening maturities when yields are below historical averages. 
(c)  Liquidity. The Town will structure its portfolio so that securities mature in advance of anticipated cash requirements (static liquidity). The maturity structure of the portfolio will be supported by a cash forecasting method that will be updated quarterly. The portfolio will be invested in securities supported by active secondary or resale markets (dynamic liquidity) to provide cash through the sale of securities in the event that it is necessary. 
(d)  Yield. The Town will not compromise its safety or liquidity objectives for the purpose of potential yield enhancement. Investments are limited to relatively low-risk securities in anticipation of earning a market rate of return on the security and maturity selected at the time the investment was placed. While it may be necessary from time to time to sell a security prior to its maturity to meet unanticipated cash needs, this policy specifically prohibits buying and selling securities for the sole purpose of realizing trading profits. 
(Ord. No. 372,  3, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-133. - Authorized investments. 
    The Town's eligible investments shall be as follows: 
(1)  Bonds, notes or other obligations of the United States for which the credit of the United States is pledged for the payment of the principal and interest or dividends thereof (F.S  215.47(1)(a) and 218.345(1)(b)). 
(2)  Securities of, or other interest in, any open-end or closed-end management type of investment company or investment trust registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940, 15 U.S.C. Section 80a-1 et seq., as amended from time to time, provided that the portfolio of such investment company or investment trust is limited to United States government obligations and to repurchase agreements fully collateralized by such United States government obligations and provided that such investment company or investment trust takes delivery of such collateral either directly or through an authorized custodian. 
(3)  Investments in securities authorized by subsection (1) above may be under repurchase agreements. All repurchase agreement transactions shall adhere to the requirements of a master repurchase agreement which is negotiated and authorized by the Town Commission. The Town will require a minimum over-collateralization of 102 percent on all repurchase agreements. 
(4)  Participation in the State Board of Administration (SBA), local government surplus trust funds investment pool. 
(Ord. No. 372,  4, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-134. - Qualifications of financial institutions. 
(a)  Broker dealers. The Town will only transact business with those broker dealers classified as primary dealers that report directly to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York with a minimum net capital of $20,000,000.00. Annual reports may be required from each primary dealer to ensure its status and minimum capital requirement. The Town may purchase or sell securities through the broker dealer of its Town-authorized financial institution. When purchasing or selling securities in excess of $2,000,000.00 through broker dealers, the selection process will be through competitive bid with a minimum of three firms contacted for each trade. 
(b)  Public depositories. The Town will only transact business with those public depositories which are listed as qualified public depositories under F.S. ch. 280. The Town will further limit the qualified public depositories to those institutions which have a branch or their main office within Broward County, Florida. 
(c)  Other financial institutions. The Town may transact business with open-end management type investment companies or investment trusts registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940, 15 U.S.C. Section 80a-1 et seq., as amended from time to time, provided that the portfolio of such investment companies or investment trusts is limited to United States Government obligations. 
(Ord. No. 372,  5, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-135. - Safekeeping and custody. 
    To protect against potential fraud and embezzlement, the assets of the Town shall be secured through third party custody and safekeeping procedures. All securities purchased by the Town under this policy shall be properly designated as assets of the Town and shall be protected through the use of a third party custodial and safekeeping agent. The third party custodian and safekeeping agent shall be selected and approved in accordance with the Town procurement policy. Whenever possible, the Town will use preformatted wire transfers to restrict the transfer of funds to preauthorized accounts. In addition, delivery versus payment procedures will be used for all eligible securities. Physical instruments, with the exception of certificates of deposit, must be delivered to and held by an approved third party institution. 
    Certificates of deposit issued by a local bank may be held in safekeeping at that institution. The institution shall issue a copy of the certificate of deposit, or other confirmation of purchase to be kept on file by the Town. The confirmation of purchase should indicate the amount, interest rate, date of issue and maturity date of the certificates of deposit. 
    Upon delivery of securities, be it in book entry or physical form, the agent shall issue a safekeeping receipt to the Town which at a minimum shall list each instrument, its rate, maturity and registration in the name of the Town. Safekeeping procedures may be reviewed annually by the Town's independent Auditor. 
(Ord. No. 372,  6, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-136. - Reporting. 
    The Town Clerk shall provide an investment portfolio report to the Town Manager annually, in conjunction with issuance of the Town's annual financial statements. This report shall contain a summary of the Town's present and matured investment securities, book value, income earned and market value for the fiscal year ending September 30. It will provide detail as to each investment held, original cost, purchase date, maturity, yield and other performance measures as may be requested. 
(Ord. No. 372,  7, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-137. - Delegation of Town. 
    The Town Clerk is designated as the primary investment officer of the Town and is responsible for investment decisions and activities. The day-to-day administration of the cash management program is handled within the Town Clerk's Office. No person may engage in an investment transaction except as provided under the terms of this policy and the procedures so established. 
    Positions authorized as investment signatories are Town Manager, Town Clerk, and Deputy Town Clerk. Other than automated overnight bank repurchase agreements, each investment transaction shall require written authorization by two investment signatories with no more than one signatory coming from the Town Clerk. The persons holding these positions are also authorized to initiate wire transfers for the Town. These investment plan procedures shall be reviewed by the Town's authorized independent auditors as part of the Town's annual financial audit. 
(Ord. No. 372,  8, 2-13-96) 
Sec. 18-138. - Prudence. 
    The standard of prudence to be applied by the investment officer shall be the "prudent person" rule, which states: "Investments shall be made with judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs, not for speculation, but for investment, considering the probable safety of their capital as well as the probable income derived." The "prudent person" rule shall be applied in the context of managing the overall portfolio. 
    The Town Clerk and staff, acting in accordance with these written procedures and exercising due diligence, shall not be held personally responsible for a specific security's credit risk or market price changes, provided that these deviations are reported immediately and that appropriate action is taken to control adverse developments. 
(Ord. No. 372,  9, 2-13-96) 
Chapter 19 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Beaches and waterways, Ch. 5; operating vehicles on the beach,  5-25; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 8; flood prevention and control, Ch. 9; noise, Ch. 13; offenses, Ch. 14; police, Ch. 15; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; placing glass, tacks, etc., upon roadway prohibited,  17-8; operation of vehicles damaging streets prohibited,  17-10; spilling of rocks, etc., from trucks prohibited,  17-1; signs, 24-6.1 et seq. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles, F.S.  316.001 et seq.; powers of local authorities, F.S.  316.008; uniform disposition of traffic infractions act, F.S. Ch. 318. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Adoption of Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, F.S. ch. 316, as amended, which law shall be in full force and effect in the Town as if fully set forth herein, and shall be considered as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09,  2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 19-2. - Adoption of Florida Uniform Disposition of Traffic Infractions Act. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference the Florida Uniform Disposition of Traffic Infractions Act, F.S. ch. 318, as amended, which act shall be in full force and effect in the Town as if fully set forth herein, and shall be considered as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09,  2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 19-3. - Supplying parking violation information to the State. 
    The Town of Lauderdale-By-The-Sea shall supply the Florida Department of Safety and Motor Vehicles, or any successor department performing substantially the same duties, a list of persons who have three or more outstanding parking violations, or one or more outstanding parking violation(s) of F.S.  316.1955, 316.1956, or any Town ordinances which regulate parking in spaces for persons with disabilities. The information may be supplied to the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles in any communication format approved by it or State statute. 
(Ord. No. 2004-09,  1, 6-22-04; Ord. No. 2011-09,  2, 5-24-2011) 
Sec. 19-4. - Enforcement of traffic and parking regulations. 
(a)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Violations pertaining to the improper parking or storage of a motor vehicle shall be in conformity with the provisions of the Florida Uniform Traffic Laws as provided in Florida Statutes. 
(2)  A violation(s) of this section shall be prosecuted in accordance with F.S. ch. 162, or through any other supplemental municipal code or ordinance enforcement procedures available to the Town under the Florida Statutes, this Code, or both. 
(3)  Any violation of this section shall constitute a nuisance. The Town Attorney may bring suit on behalf of the Town, or any affected citizen may bring suit in his/her name against the person or persons causing or maintaining the violation, or against the owner/agent of the building or property on which the violation exists. Relief may be granted according to the terms and conditions of F.S. ch. 60, entitled Abatement of Nuisances. 
(4)  Parking violations are to be paid within 21 calendar days from the date of issuance of a citation. 
(5)  Parking violation fines for which full payment is not received within 21 calendar days from the date of issuance will be subject to a $15.00 penalty in addition to the citation fine for each citation issued. 
(6)  Parking violation fines and penalties for which full payment is not received within 45 calendar days from the date of issuance will be subject to an additional $20.00 penalty, for a total penalty of $35.00, in addition to the citation fine for each citation issued. 
(7)  Pursuant to F.S.  938.35, parking violation fines and penalties for which full payment is not received within 90 calendar days from the date of issuance will also be subject to an additional collection fee if the account is referred to a private attorney or a collection agent registered pursuant to F.S. ch. 559, either retained by the Town to pursue the collection of such unpaid financial obligations. The amount of such collection fee shall not exceed 40 percent of the amount owed at the time the account is referred to the attorney or agents for collection, or in the actual amount charged by such private attorney or agents for collection, whichever is less. 
(8)  In the case of overpayment of a parking violation fine and penalty, no refund shall be made if payment of any other delinquent citation is due and owing on any vehicle owned by the same registered owner of the vehicle. The Town shall apply such credit balance to the oldest outstanding delinquent citation first. 
(b)  Overtime, permit or restricted parking-Penalty and enforcement. The penalty for overtime parking or for parking in any space requiring a permit, or for any space that may be restricted in any manner, shall be $25.00. 
(c)  Citation dismissal. The Town Manager or his/her designee may dismiss parking citations under certain extenuating circumstances. These circumstances may include, but are not limited to, an improperly displayed permit or meter receipt when a valid permit or receipt is later produced for disabled vehicle; verified official city business; ambulance transport; police department undercover vehicles; utility service providers; error in the information on the citation; or verified meter malfunction. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09,  2, 5-24-2011) 
Secs. 19-5-19-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING, STOPPING OR STANDING 

Sec. 19-21. - Parking or storage of motor vehicles and vessels. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
(1)  Commercial motor vehicle or commercial vehicle means any motor vehicle that has one or more of the following characteristics: 
a.  Weighs in excess of 10,000 pounds. The weight of the vehicle as listed on the vehicle registration is prima facia evidence of the weight of the vehicle; 
b.  Is designed to transport more than ten people; 
c.  Is used in commerce; 
d.  Displays lettering, signs or advertising identifying a business or other non-personal use of any kind; 
e.  Possesses built-in, exterior storage compartments; 
f.  Holds tools, equipment, supplies or any other material, refuse or debris that is clearly visible; or 
g.  Has fixtures or attachments on the exterior of the vehicle utilized to hold tools, supplies or equipment; or 
h.  Is otherwise defined by reference to F.S. ch. 320, as a truck/tractor, semi-trailer, bus, ambulance, trailer, wrecker, hearse or truck, except that pick-up trucks are not prohibited unless it otherwise falls within one of the classifications of commercial vehicle as provided herein. 
i.  The definition of commercial vehicle shall not include a vehicle owned by a governmental agency. 
(2)  East zone includes all property east of the western property line of those properties abutting State Road A1A to the west. 
(3)  For-hire vehicle means any vehicle when used for transporting persons or goods for compensation. 
(4)  Motor home means a movable structure designed for use as a temporary or permanent place of dwelling. 
(5)  Motor vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle, including a motorcycle, not operated upon rails or guideway, but not including any bicycle, motorized scooter, electric personal assistive mobility device, or moped. 
(6)  Overnight parking means parking between the hours of midnight and 5:00 a.m. 
(7)  Parking facility means any publicly owned parking lot, parking garage, parking space or parking area. 
(8)  Parking meter means any mechanical or electronic device used to regulate parking by collecting revenue in exchange for the right to park a vehicle in a particular place for a limited amount of time. 
(9)  Personal watercraft means any vessel which uses an outboard motor, or an inboard motor powering a water jet pump, as its primary source of motive power and which is designed to be operated by a person sitting, standing, or kneeling on, or being towed behind the vessel, rather than in the conventional manner of sitting or standing inside the vessel. The term "personal watercraft" shall include, but is not limited to, those vessels commonly referred to as jet skis, wave runners, sea doos or surf rockets. The term "personal watercraft" shall not apply to any such vessel operated by a governmental agency which provides emergency services. 
(10)  Recreational vehicle means any vehicle or portable structure designed primarily to provide temporary living quarters for recreation, camping or travel use either a vehicular structure mounted on wheels, self-powered or designed to be pulled by another vehicle or a structure designed to be mounted upon and carried by another vehicle. This definition includes, but is not limited to, any vehicle listed below as may be further defined by reference to Florida Statutes as a travel trailer, camping trailer, camp bus or house bus, truck camper, motor home, mobile home, motor coach, or fifth-wheel trailer. 
(11)  Registered vehicle or registered vessel shall mean any vehicle or vessel that is issued a current State-issued certificate of registration. 
(12)  Right-of-way or ROW means the surface and space on, above and below any real property in which the Town has an interest in law or equity, whether held in fee, easement, dedication, plat or other estate or interest open to travel by the public, including but not limited to any public street, boulevard, road, highway, freeway, lane, alley, court, sidewalk, or bridge. 
(13)  Swale means the area between a travel lane and the sidewalk or private property line, whichever is closest. 
(14)  Trailer means any vehicle without motive power designed to be coupled to or drawn by a motor vehicle and constructed so that no part of its weight or that of its load rests upon the towing vehicle. 
(15)  Vessel includes every description of boat, watercraft, barge and airboat used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water. 
(16)  West zone shall be from the western property line of those properties abutting State Road A1A to the west extending to the western boundary of the Town. 
(b)  Restrictions and prohibitions. In the east and west zones as defined in this section, vessels, commercial vehicles and recreational vehicles are prohibited and restricted as hereinafter set forth. 
(1)  Commercial vehicles, recreational vehicles and vessels are prohibited from being parked overnight in a metered parking space within the Town. 
(2)  Unregistered commercial vehicles, recreational vehicles or vessels are prohibited from being parked or stored within the boundaries of the Town unless wholly enclosed within a garage. 
(3)  East zone. 
a.  Registered commercial vehicles or recreational vehicles must comply with the following: 
1.  At all times, the vehicle must fit within the single parking space within which it is parked unless it is parked in a private parking lot obscured from view from the street and neighboring properties. 
2.  The vehicle cannot protrude into a side or rear setback, sidewalk or right-of-way. 
3.  The vehicle must be parked on concrete, asphalt, or some other type of impervious ground cover as approved by the Town and may not be parked, stored, or maintained on the grass. 
b.  Registered vessels, personal watercraft and their trailers may be parked, stored or maintained in the Town on private property with the consent of the owner, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Vessels, personal watercraft and their trailers are prohibited from protruding into a sidewalk or right-of-way. 
2.  The vessel, personal watercraft and its trailer must be parked on concrete, asphalt or some other type of impervious ground cover as approved by the Town and may not be parked or stored on grass. 
3.  Vessels and personal watercraft under 21 feet in length and under ten feet in height may be stored in the rear of the private property only if it is covered and cannot be seen from the street or the neighboring properties. 
c.  No commercial vehicle, recreational vehicle, vessel, personal watercraft or trailer shall be parked, stored or maintained: 
1.  So as to be visible from Bougainvilla Drive; 
2.  On any portion of the public or private beaches. 
(4)  West zone. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person to park, store or maintain any commercial vehicle, recreational vehicle, vessel, personal watercraft or trailer on the streets, rights-of-way, or public or private property in any district of the Town located in the west zone between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. except as provided below. 
b.  Uses not prohibited. Nothing herein shall prohibit the parking of commercial vehicles in the west zone while in the process of making deliveries or service calls. 
c.  Commercial vehicles, recreational vehicles, vessels, personal watercrafts or trailers must be wholly enclosed within a garage or enclosed within a carport surrounding the vehicle on three sides and the vessel or vehicle does not protrude from the carport. 
d.  A for-hire vehicle utilized for the temporary moving of personal property may be parked in view overnight, with a temporary permit issued by the Town, not to exceed three nights. 
e.  Registered vessels, personal watercraft and their trailers may be parked, stored or maintained in the west zone of the Town on private property with the consent of the owner, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Neither the vessel nor its trailer may protrude into a side or rear setback. The enforcement of this provision shall be deferred until January 25, 2001 for any vessel owned prior to July 1, 2000 provided said vessel is registered with the Town Police Department prior to July 1, 2000. 
2.  The vessel, personal watercraft or vehicle must be wholly enclosed within a garage or enclosed within a carport surrounding the vessel or vehicle on three sides and the vessel, personal watercraft or vehicle does not protrude from the carport. The enforcement of this provision shall be deferred until January 25, 2001 for any vessel owned prior to July 1, 2000 provided said vessel is registered with the Town Police Department prior to July 1, 2000. 
3.  The vessel and its trailer must be parked on concrete, asphalt or some other type of impervious ground cover as approved by the Town and may not be parked, stored or maintained on the grass. 
4.  Vessels under 21 feet in length and under ten feet in height and personal watercraft may be stored in the rear of the private property only if it is covered and cannot be seen from the street or the neighboring properties. 
f.
